references: Mitchell, J. C. 1991. Amphibians and reptiles. Pages 411-76 in K. Terwilliger (coordinator). Virginia's Endangered Species:Proceedings of a Symposium. McDonald and Woodward Publishing Company, Blacksburg, Virginia.
Kramer, P., N. Reichenbach, M. Hayslett, and P. Sattler. 1993. Population dynamics and conservation of the Peaks of Otter salamander, Plethodon hubrichti. Journal of Herpetology 27:431–435.
Bury, R. B., C. K. Dodd, Jr., and G. M. Fellers. 1980. Conservation of the Amphibia of the United States:a review. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Washington, D.C., Resource Publication 134. 34 pp.
Highton, R. 1986. Plethodon hubrichti. Catalogue of American Amphibians and Reptiles 393: 1-2.
Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
habitat_description: The Peaks of Otter Salamander is closely related to other relict mountaintop Plethodons (P. shenandoah and P. nettingi).   They are locally abundant in mature hardwood forest, mainly on north-facing slopes and in coves in the Peaks of Otter region of west-central Virginia.   They are also found in shaded ravines and rhododendron thickets.  They are generally found above 845 m (Petranka 1998).  They can be found primarily under downed logs and rocks, and among wet leaf litter, in middle to late successional stages of oak-maple woodland (Bury et al. 1980, Mitchell 1991).  They often climb into vegetation, especially ferns, in June-September (Kramer et al. 1993).  They may be vulnerable to habitat fragmentation. They are terrestrial breeders.
